title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. Prohibited acts under the legislation include importing, exporting, or transporting fur from animals trapped in steel-jawed leghold traps, as well as selling or acquiring such traps. Penalties for violations include imprisonment for up to 5 days or fines for first offenses, and up to two years for subsequent violations. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees in official capacity are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations. Enforcement authorities can take action, excluding violations covered under subsection (b). Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages if they suspect a violation of the Act. They can also make arrests without a warrant if they witness a violation or have probable cause. Additionally, they can execute warrants issued by a judge for criminal processes. Enforcement authorities can detain, search, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. They can make arrests without a warrant if they witness a violation or have probable cause. Warrants issued by judges for criminal processes can also be executed. Any fur or steel-jawed leghold trap article in violation of the Act is subject to forfeiture to the United States. The Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of property for violations, with procedures similar to customs laws. Enforcement duties can be carried out by the Secretary or designated officers, or other agencies with authority to manage seized property. The Attorney General may seek injunctions against violators of the Act. The Secretary of Commerce, Treasury, and other relevant agencies must cooperate in enforcing the Act effectively. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to any furskin or article made in whole or part of furskin. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. "Import" means to bring into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior may create rules to implement the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
